Mpeg2Settings' :: Maybe Mpeg2ScanType -> Maybe Mpeg2DisplayRatio -> Maybe Mpeg2ColorMetadata -> Maybe Mpeg2GopSizeUnits -> Maybe Mpeg2SubGopLength -> Maybe FixedAfd -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Mpeg2FilterSettings -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Mpeg2TimecodeInsertionBehavior -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Mpeg2ColorSpace -> Maybe Mpeg2AdaptiveQuantization -> Maybe AfdSignaling -> Natural -> Natural -> Mpeg2Settings

-- | Set the scan type of the output to PROGRESSIVE or INTERLACED (top
--   field first).
[$sel:scanType:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2ScanType

-- | Sets the pixel aspect ratio for the encode.
[$sel:displayAspectRatio:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2DisplayRatio

-- | Specifies whether to include the color space metadata. The metadata
--   describes the color space that applies to the video (the colorSpace
--   field). We recommend that you insert the metadata.
[$sel:colorMetadata:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2ColorMetadata

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. Specifies whether the gopSize is
--   specified in frames or seconds. If you do not plan to change the
--   default gopSize, leave the default. If you specify SECONDS, MediaLive
--   will internally convert the gop size to a frame count.
[$sel:gopSizeUnits:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2GopSizeUnits

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. If you do not know what GOP is, use the
--   default. FIXED: Set the number of B-frames in each sub-GOP to the
--   value in gopNumBFrames. DYNAMIC: Let MediaLive optimize the number of
--   B-frames in each sub-GOP, to improve visual quality.
[$sel:subgopLength:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2SubGopLength

-- | Complete this field only when afdSignaling is set to FIXED. Enter the
--   AFD value (4 bits) to write on all frames of the video encode.
[$sel:fixedAfd:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe FixedAfd

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. The GOP size (keyframe interval) in the
--   units specified in gopSizeUnits. If you do not know what GOP is, use
--   the default. If gopSizeUnits is frames, then the gopSize must be an
--   integer and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is
--   seconds, the gopSize must be greater than 0, but does not need to be
--   an integer.
[$sel:gopSize:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Double

-- | Optionally specify a noise reduction filter, which can improve quality
--   of compressed content. If you do not choose a filter, no filter will
--   be applied. TEMPORAL: This filter is useful for both source content
--   that is noisy (when it has excessive digital artifacts) and source
--   content that is clean. When the content is noisy, the filter cleans up
--   the source content before the encoding phase, with these two effects:
--   First, it improves the output video quality because the content has
--   been cleaned up. Secondly, it decreases the bandwidth because
--   MediaLive does not waste bits on encoding noise. When the content is
--   reasonably clean, the filter tends to decrease the bitrate.
[$sel:filterSettings:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2FilterSettings

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. The number of B-frames between reference
--   frames. If you do not know what a B-frame is, use the default.
[$sel:gopNumBFrames:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Determines how MediaLive inserts timecodes in the output video. For
--   detailed information about setting up the input and the output for a
--   timecode, see the section on \"MediaLive Features - Timecode
--   configuration\" in the MediaLive User Guide. DISABLED: do not include
--   timecodes. GOP_TIMECODE: Include timecode metadata in the GOP header.
[$sel:timecodeInsertion:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2TimecodeInsertionBehavior

-- | MPEG2: default is open GOP.
[$sel:gopClosedCadence:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Choose the type of color space conversion to apply to the output. For
--   detailed information on setting up both the input and the output to
--   obtain the desired color space in the output, see the section on
--   \"MediaLive Features - Video - color space\" in the MediaLive User
--   Guide. PASSTHROUGH: Keep the color space of the input content - do not
--   convert it. AUTO:Convert all content that is SD to rec 601, and
--   convert all content that is HD to rec 709.
[$sel:colorSpace:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2ColorSpace

-- | Choose Off to disable adaptive quantization. Or choose another value
--   to enable the quantizer and set its strength. The strengths are: Auto,
--   Off, Low, Medium, High. When you enable this field, MediaLive allows
--   intra-frame quantizers to vary, which might improve visual quality.
[$sel:adaptiveQuantization:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe Mpeg2AdaptiveQuantization

-- | Indicates the AFD values that MediaLive will write into the video
--   encode. If you do not know what AFD signaling is, or if your
--   downstream system has not given you guidance, choose AUTO. AUTO:
--   MediaLive will try to preserve the input AFD value (in cases where
--   multiple AFD values are valid). FIXED: MediaLive will use the value
--   you specify in fixedAFD.
[$sel:afdSignaling:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Maybe AfdSignaling

-- | The framerate numerator. For example, 24000. The framerate is the
--   numerator divided by the denominator. For example, 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 FPS.
[$sel:framerateNumerator:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Natural

-- | description": "The framerate denominator. For example, 1001. The
--   framerate is the numerator divided by the denominator. For example,
--   24000 / 1001 = 23.976 FPS.
[$sel:framerateDenominator:Mpeg2Settings'] :: Mpeg2Settings -> Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>Mpeg2Settings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:scanType:Mpeg2Settings'</a>, <a>mpeg2Settings_scanType</a> -
--   Set the scan type of the output to PROGRESSIVE or INTERLACED (top
--   field first).
--   
--   <a>$sel:displayAspectRatio:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_displayAspectRatio</a> - Sets the pixel aspect ratio
--   for the encode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorMetadata:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_colorMetadata</a> - Specifies whether to include the
--   color space metadata. The metadata describes the color space that
--   applies to the video (the colorSpace field). We recommend that you
--   insert the metadata.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSizeUnits:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_gopSizeUnits</a> - Relates to the GOP structure.
--   Specifies whether the gopSize is specified in frames or seconds. If
--   you do not plan to change the default gopSize, leave the default. If
--   you specify SECONDS, MediaLive will internally convert the gop size to
--   a frame count.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subgopLength:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_subgopLength</a> - Relates to the GOP structure. If
--   you do not know what GOP is, use the default. FIXED: Set the number of
--   B-frames in each sub-GOP to the value in gopNumBFrames. DYNAMIC: Let
--   MediaLive optimize the number of B-frames in each sub-GOP, to improve
--   visual quality.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fixedAfd:Mpeg2Settings'</a>, <a>mpeg2Settings_fixedAfd</a> -
--   Complete this field only when afdSignaling is set to FIXED. Enter the
--   AFD value (4 bits) to write on all frames of the video encode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSize:Mpeg2Settings'</a>, <a>mpeg2Settings_gopSize</a> -
--   Relates to the GOP structure. The GOP size (keyframe interval) in the
--   units specified in gopSizeUnits. If you do not know what GOP is, use
--   the default. If gopSizeUnits is frames, then the gopSize must be an
--   integer and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is
--   seconds, the gopSize must be greater than 0, but does not need to be
--   an integer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:filterSettings:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_filterSettings</a> - Optionally specify a noise
--   reduction filter, which can improve quality of compressed content. If
--   you do not choose a filter, no filter will be applied. TEMPORAL: This
--   filter is useful for both source content that is noisy (when it has
--   excessive digital artifacts) and source content that is clean. When
--   the content is noisy, the filter cleans up the source content before
--   the encoding phase, with these two effects: First, it improves the
--   output video quality because the content has been cleaned up.
--   Secondly, it decreases the bandwidth because MediaLive does not waste
--   bits on encoding noise. When the content is reasonably clean, the
--   filter tends to decrease the bitrate.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopNumBFrames:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_gopNumBFrames</a> - Relates to the GOP structure. The
--   number of B-frames between reference frames. If you do not know what a
--   B-frame is, use the default.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timecodeInsertion:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_timecodeInsertion</a> - Determines how MediaLive
--   inserts timecodes in the output video. For detailed information about
--   setting up the input and the output for a timecode, see the section on
--   \"MediaLive Features - Timecode configuration\" in the MediaLive User
--   Guide. DISABLED: do not include timecodes. GOP_TIMECODE: Include
--   timecode metadata in the GOP header.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopClosedCadence:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_gopClosedCadence</a> - MPEG2: default is open GOP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorSpace:Mpeg2Settings'</a>, <a>mpeg2Settings_colorSpace</a>
--   - Choose the type of color space conversion to apply to the output.
--   For detailed information on setting up both the input and the output
--   to obtain the desired color space in the output, see the section on
--   \"MediaLive Features - Video - color space\" in the MediaLive User
--   Guide. PASSTHROUGH: Keep the color space of the input content - do not
--   convert it. AUTO:Convert all content that is SD to rec 601, and
--   convert all content that is HD to rec 709.
--   
--   <a>$sel:adaptiveQuantization:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_adaptiveQuantization</a> - Choose Off to disable
--   adaptive quantization. Or choose another value to enable the quantizer
--   and set its strength. The strengths are: Auto, Off, Low, Medium, High.
--   When you enable this field, MediaLive allows intra-frame quantizers to
--   vary, which might improve visual quality.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afdSignaling:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_afdSignaling</a> - Indicates the AFD values that
--   MediaLive will write into the video encode. If you do not know what
--   AFD signaling is, or if your downstream system has not given you
--   guidance, choose AUTO. AUTO: MediaLive will try to preserve the input
--   AFD value (in cases where multiple AFD values are valid). FIXED:
--   MediaLive will use the value you specify in fixedAFD.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateNumerator:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_framerateNumerator</a> - The framerate numerator. For
--   example, 24000. The framerate is the numerator divided by the
--   denominator. For example, 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 FPS.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateDenominator:Mpeg2Settings'</a>,
--   <a>mpeg2Settings_framerateDenominator</a> - description": "The
--   framerate denominator. For example, 1001. The framerate is the
--   numerator divided by the denominator. For example, 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 FPS.
newMpeg2Settings :: Natural -> Natural -> Mpeg2Settings

-- | Set the scan type of the output to PROGRESSIVE or INTERLACED (top
--   field first).
mpeg2Settings_scanType :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2ScanType)

-- | Sets the pixel aspect ratio for the encode.
mpeg2Settings_displayAspectRatio :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2DisplayRatio)

-- | Specifies whether to include the color space metadata. The metadata
--   describes the color space that applies to the video (the colorSpace
--   field). We recommend that you insert the metadata.
mpeg2Settings_colorMetadata :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2ColorMetadata)

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. Specifies whether the gopSize is
--   specified in frames or seconds. If you do not plan to change the
--   default gopSize, leave the default. If you specify SECONDS, MediaLive
--   will internally convert the gop size to a frame count.
mpeg2Settings_gopSizeUnits :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2GopSizeUnits)

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. If you do not know what GOP is, use the
--   default. FIXED: Set the number of B-frames in each sub-GOP to the
--   value in gopNumBFrames. DYNAMIC: Let MediaLive optimize the number of
--   B-frames in each sub-GOP, to improve visual quality.
mpeg2Settings_subgopLength :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2SubGopLength)

-- | Complete this field only when afdSignaling is set to FIXED. Enter the
--   AFD value (4 bits) to write on all frames of the video encode.
mpeg2Settings_fixedAfd :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe FixedAfd)

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. The GOP size (keyframe interval) in the
--   units specified in gopSizeUnits. If you do not know what GOP is, use
--   the default. If gopSizeUnits is frames, then the gopSize must be an
--   integer and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is
--   seconds, the gopSize must be greater than 0, but does not need to be
--   an integer.
mpeg2Settings_gopSize :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Double)

-- | Optionally specify a noise reduction filter, which can improve quality
--   of compressed content. If you do not choose a filter, no filter will
--   be applied. TEMPORAL: This filter is useful for both source content
--   that is noisy (when it has excessive digital artifacts) and source
--   content that is clean. When the content is noisy, the filter cleans up
--   the source content before the encoding phase, with these two effects:
--   First, it improves the output video quality because the content has
--   been cleaned up. Secondly, it decreases the bandwidth because
--   MediaLive does not waste bits on encoding noise. When the content is
--   reasonably clean, the filter tends to decrease the bitrate.
mpeg2Settings_filterSettings :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2FilterSettings)

-- | Relates to the GOP structure. The number of B-frames between reference
--   frames. If you do not know what a B-frame is, use the default.
mpeg2Settings_gopNumBFrames :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Determines how MediaLive inserts timecodes in the output video. For
--   detailed information about setting up the input and the output for a
--   timecode, see the section on \"MediaLive Features - Timecode
--   configuration\" in the MediaLive User Guide. DISABLED: do not include
--   timecodes. GOP_TIMECODE: Include timecode metadata in the GOP header.
mpeg2Settings_timecodeInsertion :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2TimecodeInsertionBehavior)

-- | MPEG2: default is open GOP.
mpeg2Settings_gopClosedCadence :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Choose the type of color space conversion to apply to the output. For
--   detailed information on setting up both the input and the output to
--   obtain the desired color space in the output, see the section on
--   \"MediaLive Features - Video - color space\" in the MediaLive User
--   Guide. PASSTHROUGH: Keep the color space of the input content - do not
--   convert it. AUTO:Convert all content that is SD to rec 601, and
--   convert all content that is HD to rec 709.
mpeg2Settings_colorSpace :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2ColorSpace)

-- | Choose Off to disable adaptive quantization. Or choose another value
--   to enable the quantizer and set its strength. The strengths are: Auto,
--   Off, Low, Medium, High. When you enable this field, MediaLive allows
--   intra-frame quantizers to vary, which might improve visual quality.
mpeg2Settings_adaptiveQuantization :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe Mpeg2AdaptiveQuantization)

-- | Indicates the AFD values that MediaLive will write into the video
--   encode. If you do not know what AFD signaling is, or if your
--   downstream system has not given you guidance, choose AUTO. AUTO:
--   MediaLive will try to preserve the input AFD value (in cases where
--   multiple AFD values are valid). FIXED: MediaLive will use the value
--   you specify in fixedAFD.
mpeg2Settings_afdSignaling :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings (Maybe AfdSignaling)

-- | The framerate numerator. For example, 24000. The framerate is the
--   numerator divided by the denominator. For example, 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 FPS.
mpeg2Settings_framerateNumerator :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings Natural

-- | description": "The framerate denominator. For example, 1001. The
--   framerate is the numerator divided by the denominator. For example,
--   24000 / 1001 = 23.976 FPS.
mpeg2Settings_framerateDenominator :: Lens' Mpeg2Settings Natural
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.Mpeg2Settings.Mpeg2Settings


module Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings

-- | H265 Filter Settings
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newH265FilterSettings</a> smart constructor.
data H265FilterSettings
H265FilterSettings' :: Maybe TemporalFilterSettings -> H265FilterSettings
[$sel:temporalFilterSettings:H265FilterSettings'] :: H265FilterSettings -> Maybe TemporalFilterSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>H265FilterSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:temporalFilterSettings:H265FilterSettings'</a>,
--   <a>h265FilterSettings_temporalFilterSettings</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
newH265FilterSettings :: H265FilterSettings

-- | Undocumented member.
h265FilterSettings_temporalFilterSettings :: Lens' H265FilterSettings (Maybe TemporalFilterSettings)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265FilterSettings.H265FilterSettings


module Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings

-- | H265 Settings
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newH265Settings</a> smart constructor.
data H265Settings
H265Settings' :: Maybe H265ScanType -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H265FlickerAq -> Maybe H265RateControlMode -> Maybe H265AlternativeTransferFunction -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H265ColorMetadata -> Maybe H265GopSizeUnits -> Maybe FixedAfd -> Maybe Double -> Maybe H265FilterSettings -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H265TimecodeInsertionBehavior -> Maybe H265SceneChangeDetect -> Maybe H265ColorSpaceSettings -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H265Level -> Maybe H265LookAheadRateControl -> Maybe H265Profile -> Maybe H265AdaptiveQuantization -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe AfdSignaling -> Maybe H265Tier -> Natural -> Natural -> H265Settings

-- | Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
[$sel:scanType:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265ScanType

-- | Size of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
[$sel:bufSize:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | If set to enabled, adjust quantization within each frame to reduce
--   flicker or 'pop' on I-frames.
[$sel:flickerAq:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265FlickerAq

-- | Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality will match the specified quality
--   level except when it is constrained by the maximum bitrate.
--   Recommended if you or your viewers pay for bandwidth. CBR: Quality
--   varies, depending on the video complexity. Recommended only if you
--   distribute your assets to devices that cannot handle variable
--   bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control mode is only supported (and is
--   required) when the video is being delivered to a MediaLive Multiplex
--   in which case the rate control configuration is controlled by the
--   properties within the Multiplex Program.
[$sel:rateControlMode:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265RateControlMode

-- | Whether or not EML should insert an Alternative Transfer Function SEI
--   message to support backwards compatibility with non-HDR decoders and
--   displays.
[$sel:alternativeTransferFunction:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265AlternativeTransferFunction

-- | Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number
--   of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
[$sel:slices:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Includes colorspace metadata in the output.
[$sel:colorMetadata:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265ColorMetadata

-- | Indicates if the gopSize is specified in frames or seconds. If seconds
--   the system will convert the gopSize into a frame count at run time.
[$sel:gopSizeUnits:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265GopSizeUnits

-- | Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
[$sel:fixedAfd:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe FixedAfd

-- | GOP size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
[$sel:gopSize:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Double

-- | Optional filters that you can apply to an encode.
[$sel:filterSettings:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265FilterSettings

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
[$sel:parNumerator:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Determines how timecodes should be inserted into the video elementary
--   stream. - 'disabled': Do not include timecodes - 'picTimingSei': Pass
--   through picture timing SEI messages from the source specified in
--   Timecode Config
[$sel:timecodeInsertion:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265TimecodeInsertionBehavior

-- | Scene change detection.
[$sel:sceneChangeDetect:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265SceneChangeDetect

-- | Color Space settings
[$sel:colorSpaceSettings:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265ColorSpaceSettings

-- | Only meaningful if sceneChangeDetect is set to enabled. Defaults to 5
--   if multiplex rate control is used. Enforces separation between
--   repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change
--   Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a
--   cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene
--   change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as
--   setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. Note:
--   Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
[$sel:minIInterval:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Controls the target quality for the video encode. Applies only when
--   the rate control mode is QVBR. Set values for the QVBR quality level
--   field and Max bitrate field that suit your most important viewing
--   devices. Recommended values are: - Primary screen: Quality level: 8 to
--   10. Max bitrate: 4M - PC or tablet: Quality level: 7. Max bitrate:
--   1.5M to 3M - Smartphone: Quality level: 6. Max bitrate: 1M to 1.5M
[$sel:qvbrQualityLevel:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended
--   that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an
--   IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break
--   output segmenting.
[$sel:gopClosedCadence:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio denominator.
[$sel:parDenominator:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | For QVBR: See the tooltip for Quality level
[$sel:maxBitrate:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | H.265 Level.
[$sel:level:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265Level

-- | Amount of lookahead. A value of low can decrease latency and memory
--   usage, while high can produce better quality for certain content.
[$sel:lookAheadRateControl:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265LookAheadRateControl

-- | H.265 Profile.
[$sel:profile:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265Profile

-- | Adaptive quantization. Allows intra-frame quantizers to vary to
--   improve visual quality.
[$sel:adaptiveQuantization:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265AdaptiveQuantization

-- | Average bitrate in bits/second. Required when the rate control mode is
--   VBR or CBR. Not used for QVBR. In an MS Smooth output group, each
--   output must have a unique value when its bitrate is rounded down to
--   the nearest multiple of 1000.
[$sel:bitrate:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates that AFD values will be written into the output stream. If
--   afdSignaling is "auto", the system will try to preserve the input AFD
--   value (in cases where multiple AFD values are valid). If set to
--   "fixed", the AFD value will be the value configured in the fixedAfd
--   parameter.
[$sel:afdSignaling:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe AfdSignaling

-- | H.265 Tier.
[$sel:tier:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Maybe H265Tier

-- | Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 fps.
[$sel:framerateNumerator:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Natural

-- | Framerate denominator.
[$sel:framerateDenominator:H265Settings'] :: H265Settings -> Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>H265Settings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:scanType:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_scanType</a> -
--   Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bufSize:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_bufSize</a> - Size
--   of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
--   
--   <a>$sel:flickerAq:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_flickerAq</a> -
--   If set to enabled, adjust quantization within each frame to reduce
--   flicker or 'pop' on I-frames.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rateControlMode:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_rateControlMode</a> - Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality
--   will match the specified quality level except when it is constrained
--   by the maximum bitrate. Recommended if you or your viewers pay for
--   bandwidth. CBR: Quality varies, depending on the video complexity.
--   Recommended only if you distribute your assets to devices that cannot
--   handle variable bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control mode is only
--   supported (and is required) when the video is being delivered to a
--   MediaLive Multiplex in which case the rate control configuration is
--   controlled by the properties within the Multiplex Program.
--   
--   <a>$sel:alternativeTransferFunction:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_alternativeTransferFunction</a> - Whether or not EML
--   should insert an Alternative Transfer Function SEI message to support
--   backwards compatibility with non-HDR decoders and displays.
--   
--   <a>$sel:slices:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_slices</a> - Number
--   of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number of
--   macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorMetadata:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_colorMetadata</a> - Includes colorspace metadata in
--   the output.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSizeUnits:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_gopSizeUnits</a> - Indicates if the gopSize is
--   specified in frames or seconds. If seconds the system will convert the
--   gopSize into a frame count at run time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fixedAfd:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_fixedAfd</a> -
--   Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSize:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_gopSize</a> - GOP
--   size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:filterSettings:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_filterSettings</a> - Optional filters that you can
--   apply to an encode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parNumerator:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_parNumerator</a> - Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timecodeInsertion:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_timecodeInsertion</a> - Determines how timecodes
--   should be inserted into the video elementary stream. - 'disabled': Do
--   not include timecodes - 'picTimingSei': Pass through picture timing
--   SEI messages from the source specified in Timecode Config
--   
--   <a>$sel:sceneChangeDetect:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_sceneChangeDetect</a> - Scene change detection.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorSpaceSettings:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_colorSpaceSettings</a> - Color Space settings
--   
--   <a>$sel:minIInterval:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_minIInterval</a> - Only meaningful if
--   sceneChangeDetect is set to enabled. Defaults to 5 if multiplex rate
--   control is used. Enforces separation between repeated (cadence)
--   I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change Detection. If a scene
--   change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a cadence I-frame, the
--   GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene change I-frame. GOP
--   stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as setting I-interval. The
--   normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. Note: Maximum GOP stretch =
--   GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
--   
--   <a>$sel:qvbrQualityLevel:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_qvbrQualityLevel</a> - Controls the target quality for
--   the video encode. Applies only when the rate control mode is QVBR. Set
--   values for the QVBR quality level field and Max bitrate field that
--   suit your most important viewing devices. Recommended values are: -
--   Primary screen: Quality level: 8 to 10. Max bitrate: 4M - PC or
--   tablet: Quality level: 7. Max bitrate: 1.5M to 3M - Smartphone:
--   Quality level: 6. Max bitrate: 1M to 1.5M
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopClosedCadence:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_gopClosedCadence</a> - Frequency of closed GOPs. In
--   streaming applications, it is recommended that this be set to 1 so a
--   decoder joining mid-stream will receive an IDR frame as quickly as
--   possible. Setting this value to 0 will break output segmenting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parDenominator:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_parDenominator</a> - Pixel Aspect Ratio denominator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxBitrate:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_maxBitrate</a> -
--   For QVBR: See the tooltip for Quality level
--   
--   <a>$sel:level:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_level</a> - H.265
--   Level.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lookAheadRateControl:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_lookAheadRateControl</a> - Amount of lookahead. A
--   value of low can decrease latency and memory usage, while high can
--   produce better quality for certain content.
--   
--   <a>$sel:profile:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_profile</a> - H.265
--   Profile.
--   
--   <a>$sel:adaptiveQuantization:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_adaptiveQuantization</a> - Adaptive quantization.
--   Allows intra-frame quantizers to vary to improve visual quality.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bitrate:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_bitrate</a> -
--   Average bitrate in bits/second. Required when the rate control mode is
--   VBR or CBR. Not used for QVBR. In an MS Smooth output group, each
--   output must have a unique value when its bitrate is rounded down to
--   the nearest multiple of 1000.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afdSignaling:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_afdSignaling</a> - Indicates that AFD values will be
--   written into the output stream. If afdSignaling is "auto", the system
--   will try to preserve the input AFD value (in cases where multiple AFD
--   values are valid). If set to "fixed", the AFD value will be the value
--   configured in the fixedAfd parameter.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tier:H265Settings'</a>, <a>h265Settings_tier</a> - H.265 Tier.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateNumerator:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_framerateNumerator</a> - Framerate numerator -
--   framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateDenominator:H265Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h265Settings_framerateDenominator</a> - Framerate denominator.
newH265Settings :: Natural -> Natural -> H265Settings

-- | Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
h265Settings_scanType :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265ScanType)

-- | Size of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
h265Settings_bufSize :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | If set to enabled, adjust quantization within each frame to reduce
--   flicker or 'pop' on I-frames.
h265Settings_flickerAq :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265FlickerAq)

-- | Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality will match the specified quality
--   level except when it is constrained by the maximum bitrate.
--   Recommended if you or your viewers pay for bandwidth. CBR: Quality
--   varies, depending on the video complexity. Recommended only if you
--   distribute your assets to devices that cannot handle variable
--   bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control mode is only supported (and is
--   required) when the video is being delivered to a MediaLive Multiplex
--   in which case the rate control configuration is controlled by the
--   properties within the Multiplex Program.
h265Settings_rateControlMode :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265RateControlMode)

-- | Whether or not EML should insert an Alternative Transfer Function SEI
--   message to support backwards compatibility with non-HDR decoders and
--   displays.
h265Settings_alternativeTransferFunction :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265AlternativeTransferFunction)

-- | Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number
--   of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
h265Settings_slices :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Includes colorspace metadata in the output.
h265Settings_colorMetadata :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265ColorMetadata)

-- | Indicates if the gopSize is specified in frames or seconds. If seconds
--   the system will convert the gopSize into a frame count at run time.
h265Settings_gopSizeUnits :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265GopSizeUnits)

-- | Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
h265Settings_fixedAfd :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe FixedAfd)

-- | GOP size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
h265Settings_gopSize :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Double)

-- | Optional filters that you can apply to an encode.
h265Settings_filterSettings :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265FilterSettings)

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
h265Settings_parNumerator :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Determines how timecodes should be inserted into the video elementary
--   stream. - 'disabled': Do not include timecodes - 'picTimingSei': Pass
--   through picture timing SEI messages from the source specified in
--   Timecode Config
h265Settings_timecodeInsertion :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265TimecodeInsertionBehavior)

-- | Scene change detection.
h265Settings_sceneChangeDetect :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265SceneChangeDetect)

-- | Color Space settings
h265Settings_colorSpaceSettings :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265ColorSpaceSettings)

-- | Only meaningful if sceneChangeDetect is set to enabled. Defaults to 5
--   if multiplex rate control is used. Enforces separation between
--   repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change
--   Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a
--   cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene
--   change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as
--   setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. Note:
--   Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
h265Settings_minIInterval :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Controls the target quality for the video encode. Applies only when
--   the rate control mode is QVBR. Set values for the QVBR quality level
--   field and Max bitrate field that suit your most important viewing
--   devices. Recommended values are: - Primary screen: Quality level: 8 to
--   10. Max bitrate: 4M - PC or tablet: Quality level: 7. Max bitrate:
--   1.5M to 3M - Smartphone: Quality level: 6. Max bitrate: 1M to 1.5M
h265Settings_qvbrQualityLevel :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended
--   that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an
--   IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break
--   output segmenting.
h265Settings_gopClosedCadence :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio denominator.
h265Settings_parDenominator :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | For QVBR: See the tooltip for Quality level
h265Settings_maxBitrate :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | H.265 Level.
h265Settings_level :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265Level)

-- | Amount of lookahead. A value of low can decrease latency and memory
--   usage, while high can produce better quality for certain content.
h265Settings_lookAheadRateControl :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265LookAheadRateControl)

-- | H.265 Profile.
h265Settings_profile :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265Profile)

-- | Adaptive quantization. Allows intra-frame quantizers to vary to
--   improve visual quality.
h265Settings_adaptiveQuantization :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265AdaptiveQuantization)

-- | Average bitrate in bits/second. Required when the rate control mode is
--   VBR or CBR. Not used for QVBR. In an MS Smooth output group, each
--   output must have a unique value when its bitrate is rounded down to
--   the nearest multiple of 1000.
h265Settings_bitrate :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates that AFD values will be written into the output stream. If
--   afdSignaling is "auto", the system will try to preserve the input AFD
--   value (in cases where multiple AFD values are valid). If set to
--   "fixed", the AFD value will be the value configured in the fixedAfd
--   parameter.
h265Settings_afdSignaling :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe AfdSignaling)

-- | H.265 Tier.
h265Settings_tier :: Lens' H265Settings (Maybe H265Tier)

-- | Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 fps.
h265Settings_framerateNumerator :: Lens' H265Settings Natural

-- | Framerate denominator.
h265Settings_framerateDenominator :: Lens' H265Settings Natural
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H265Settings.H265Settings


module Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings

-- | H264 Filter Settings
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newH264FilterSettings</a> smart constructor.
data H264FilterSettings
H264FilterSettings' :: Maybe TemporalFilterSettings -> H264FilterSettings
[$sel:temporalFilterSettings:H264FilterSettings'] :: H264FilterSettings -> Maybe TemporalFilterSettings

-- | Create a value of <a>H264FilterSettings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:temporalFilterSettings:H264FilterSettings'</a>,
--   <a>h264FilterSettings_temporalFilterSettings</a> - Undocumented
--   member.
newH264FilterSettings :: H264FilterSettings

-- | Undocumented member.
h264FilterSettings_temporalFilterSettings :: Lens' H264FilterSettings (Maybe TemporalFilterSettings)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance GHC.Show.Show Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance GHC.Read.Read Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264FilterSettings.H264FilterSettings


module Network.AWS.MediaLive.Types.H264Settings

-- | H264 Settings
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newH264Settings</a> smart constructor.
data H264Settings
H264Settings' :: Maybe H264ScanType -> Maybe H264TemporalAq -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264FlickerAq -> Maybe H264GopBReference -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264RateControlMode -> Maybe H264QualityLevel -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264ColorMetadata -> Maybe H264EntropyEncoding -> Maybe H264GopSizeUnits -> Maybe H264SubGopLength -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe FixedAfd -> Maybe Double -> Maybe H264FilterSettings -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264SpatialAq -> Maybe H264TimecodeInsertionBehavior -> Maybe H264SceneChangeDetect -> Maybe H264ParControl -> Maybe H264ColorSpaceSettings -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264Syntax -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe H264Level -> Maybe H264LookAheadRateControl -> Maybe H264Profile -> Maybe H264AdaptiveQuantization -> Maybe H264FramerateControl -> Maybe H264ForceFieldPictures -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe AfdSignaling -> H264Settings

-- | Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
[$sel:scanType:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264ScanType

-- | Temporal makes adjustments within each frame based on temporal
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if temporal AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
--   the Adaptive quantization field to a strength, you can set this field
--   to Enabled or Disabled. Enabled: MediaLive will apply temporal AQ
--   using the specified strength. Disabled: MediaLive won't apply temporal
--   AQ. If you have set the Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive
--   ignores any value in this field and doesn't apply temporal AQ.
[$sel:temporalAq:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264TemporalAq

-- | Size of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
[$sel:bufSize:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Flicker AQ makes adjustments within each frame to reduce flicker or
--   'pop' on I-frames. The value to enter in this field depends on the
--   value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have set the Adaptive
--   quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any value in this field.
--   MediaLive will determine if flicker AQ is appropriate and will apply
--   the appropriate strength. If you have set the Adaptive quantization
--   field to a strength, you can set this field to Enabled or Disabled.
--   Enabled: MediaLive will apply flicker AQ using the specified strength.
--   Disabled: MediaLive won't apply flicker AQ. If you have set the
--   Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive ignores any value in this
--   field and doesn't apply flicker AQ.
[$sel:flickerAq:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264FlickerAq

-- | Documentation update needed
[$sel:gopBReference:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264GopBReference

-- | Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 fps.
[$sel:framerateNumerator:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality will match the specified quality
--   level except when it is constrained by the maximum bitrate.
--   Recommended if you or your viewers pay for bandwidth. VBR: Quality and
--   bitrate vary, depending on the video complexity. Recommended instead
--   of QVBR if you want to maintain a specific average bitrate over the
--   duration of the channel. CBR: Quality varies, depending on the video
--   complexity. Recommended only if you distribute your assets to devices
--   that cannot handle variable bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control
--   mode is only supported (and is required) when the video is being
--   delivered to a MediaLive Multiplex in which case the rate control
--   configuration is controlled by the properties within the Multiplex
--   Program.
[$sel:rateControlMode:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264RateControlMode

-- | Leave as STANDARD_QUALITY or choose a different value (which might
--   result in additional costs to run the channel). - ENHANCED_QUALITY:
--   Produces a slightly better video quality without an increase in the
--   bitrate. Has an effect only when the Rate control mode is QVBR or CBR.
--   If this channel is in a MediaLive multiplex, the value must be
--   ENHANCED_QUALITY. - STANDARD_QUALITY: Valid for any Rate control mode.
[$sel:qualityLevel:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264QualityLevel

-- | Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number
--   of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
[$sel:slices:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Includes colorspace metadata in the output.
[$sel:colorMetadata:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264ColorMetadata

-- | Entropy encoding mode. Use cabac (must be in Main or High profile) or
--   cavlc.
[$sel:entropyEncoding:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264EntropyEncoding

-- | Indicates if the gopSize is specified in frames or seconds. If seconds
--   the system will convert the gopSize into a frame count at run time.
[$sel:gopSizeUnits:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264GopSizeUnits

-- | If set to fixed, use gopNumBFrames B-frames per sub-GOP. If set to
--   dynamic, optimize the number of B-frames used for each sub-GOP to
--   improve visual quality.
[$sel:subgopLength:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264SubGopLength

-- | Softness. Selects quantizer matrix, larger values reduce
--   high-frequency content in the encoded image. If not set to zero, must
--   be greater than 15.
[$sel:softness:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Framerate denominator.
[$sel:framerateDenominator:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
[$sel:fixedAfd:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe FixedAfd

-- | GOP size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
[$sel:gopSize:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Double

-- | Optional filters that you can apply to an encode.
[$sel:filterSettings:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264FilterSettings

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
[$sel:parNumerator:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Number of B-frames between reference frames.
[$sel:gopNumBFrames:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Spatial AQ makes adjustments within each frame based on spatial
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if spatial AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
--   the Adaptive quantization field to a strength, you can set this field
--   to Enabled or Disabled. Enabled: MediaLive will apply spatial AQ using
--   the specified strength. Disabled: MediaLive won't apply spatial AQ. If
--   you have set the Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive ignores
--   any value in this field and doesn't apply spatial AQ.
[$sel:spatialAq:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264SpatialAq

-- | Determines how timecodes should be inserted into the video elementary
--   stream. - 'disabled': Do not include timecodes - 'picTimingSei': Pass
--   through picture timing SEI messages from the source specified in
--   Timecode Config
[$sel:timecodeInsertion:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264TimecodeInsertionBehavior

-- | Scene change detection. - On: inserts I-frames when scene change is
--   detected. - Off: does not force an I-frame when scene change is
--   detected.
[$sel:sceneChangeDetect:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264SceneChangeDetect

-- | This field indicates how the output pixel aspect ratio is specified.
--   If "specified" is selected then the output video pixel aspect ratio is
--   determined by parNumerator and parDenominator, else if
--   "initializeFromSource" is selected then the output pixsel aspect ratio
--   will be set equal to the input video pixel aspect ratio of the first
--   input.
[$sel:parControl:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264ParControl

-- | Color Space settings
[$sel:colorSpaceSettings:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264ColorSpaceSettings

-- | Only meaningful if sceneChangeDetect is set to enabled. Defaults to 5
--   if multiplex rate control is used. Enforces separation between
--   repeated (cadence) I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change
--   Detection. If a scene change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a
--   cadence I-frame, the GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene
--   change I-frame. GOP stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as
--   setting I-interval. The normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. Note:
--   Maximum GOP stretch = GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
[$sel:minIInterval:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Controls the target quality for the video encode. Applies only when
--   the rate control mode is QVBR. You can set a target quality or you can
--   let MediaLive determine the best quality. To set a target quality,
--   enter values in the QVBR quality level field and the Max bitrate
--   field. Enter values that suit your most important viewing devices.
--   Recommended values are: - Primary screen: Quality level: 8 to 10. Max
--   bitrate: 4M - PC or tablet: Quality level: 7. Max bitrate: 1.5M to 3M
--   - Smartphone: Quality level: 6. Max bitrate: 1M to 1.5M To let
--   MediaLive decide, leave the QVBR quality level field empty, and in Max
--   bitrate enter the maximum rate you want in the video. For more
--   information, see the section called "Video - rate control mode" in the
--   MediaLive user guide
[$sel:qvbrQualityLevel:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Frequency of closed GOPs. In streaming applications, it is recommended
--   that this be set to 1 so a decoder joining mid-stream will receive an
--   IDR frame as quickly as possible. Setting this value to 0 will break
--   output segmenting.
[$sel:gopClosedCadence:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio denominator.
[$sel:parDenominator:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Percentage of the buffer that should initially be filled (HRD buffer
--   model).
[$sel:bufFillPct:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | For QVBR: See the tooltip for Quality level For VBR: Set the maximum
--   bitrate in order to accommodate expected spikes in the complexity of
--   the video.
[$sel:maxBitrate:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Produces a bitstream compliant with SMPTE RP-2027.
[$sel:syntax:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264Syntax

-- | Number of reference frames to use. The encoder may use more than
--   requested if using B-frames and/or interlaced encoding.
[$sel:numRefFrames:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | H.264 Level.
[$sel:level:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264Level

-- | Amount of lookahead. A value of low can decrease latency and memory
--   usage, while high can produce better quality for certain content.
[$sel:lookAheadRateControl:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264LookAheadRateControl

-- | H.264 Profile.
[$sel:profile:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264Profile

-- | Enables or disables adaptive quantization, which is a technique
--   MediaLive can apply to video on a frame-by-frame basis to produce more
--   compression without losing quality. There are three types of adaptive
--   quantization: flicker, spatial, and temporal. Set the field in one of
--   these ways: Set to Auto. Recommended. For each type of AQ, MediaLive
--   will determine if AQ is needed, and if so, the appropriate strength.
--   Set a strength (a value other than Auto or Disable). This strength
--   will apply to any of the AQ fields that you choose to enable. Set to
--   Disabled to disable all types of adaptive quantization.
[$sel:adaptiveQuantization:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264AdaptiveQuantization

-- | This field indicates how the output video frame rate is specified. If
--   "specified" is selected then the output video frame rate is determined
--   by framerateNumerator and framerateDenominator, else if
--   "initializeFromSource" is selected then the output video frame rate
--   will be set equal to the input video frame rate of the first input.
[$sel:framerateControl:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264FramerateControl

-- | This setting applies only when scan type is "interlaced." It controls
--   whether coding is performed on a field basis or on a frame basis.
--   (When the video is progressive, the coding is always performed on a
--   frame basis.) enabled: Force MediaLive to code on a field basis, so
--   that odd and even sets of fields are coded separately. disabled: Code
--   the two sets of fields separately (on a field basis) or together (on a
--   frame basis using PAFF), depending on what is most appropriate for the
--   content.
[$sel:forceFieldPictures:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe H264ForceFieldPictures

-- | Average bitrate in bits/second. Required when the rate control mode is
--   VBR or CBR. Not used for QVBR. In an MS Smooth output group, each
--   output must have a unique value when its bitrate is rounded down to
--   the nearest multiple of 1000.
[$sel:bitrate:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates that AFD values will be written into the output stream. If
--   afdSignaling is "auto", the system will try to preserve the input AFD
--   value (in cases where multiple AFD values are valid). If set to
--   "fixed", the AFD value will be the value configured in the fixedAfd
--   parameter.
[$sel:afdSignaling:H264Settings'] :: H264Settings -> Maybe AfdSignaling

-- | Create a value of <a>H264Settings</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:scanType:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_scanType</a> -
--   Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
--   
--   <a>$sel:temporalAq:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_temporalAq</a> -
--   Temporal makes adjustments within each frame based on temporal
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if temporal AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
--   the Adaptive quantization field to a strength, you can set this field
--   to Enabled or Disabled. Enabled: MediaLive will apply temporal AQ
--   using the specified strength. Disabled: MediaLive won't apply temporal
--   AQ. If you have set the Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive
--   ignores any value in this field and doesn't apply temporal AQ.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bufSize:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_bufSize</a> - Size
--   of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
--   
--   <a>$sel:flickerAq:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_flickerAq</a> -
--   Flicker AQ makes adjustments within each frame to reduce flicker or
--   'pop' on I-frames. The value to enter in this field depends on the
--   value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have set the Adaptive
--   quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any value in this field.
--   MediaLive will determine if flicker AQ is appropriate and will apply
--   the appropriate strength. If you have set the Adaptive quantization
--   field to a strength, you can set this field to Enabled or Disabled.
--   Enabled: MediaLive will apply flicker AQ using the specified strength.
--   Disabled: MediaLive won't apply flicker AQ. If you have set the
--   Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive ignores any value in this
--   field and doesn't apply flicker AQ.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopBReference:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_gopBReference</a> - Documentation update needed
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateNumerator:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_framerateNumerator</a> - Framerate numerator -
--   framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 = 23.976 fps.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rateControlMode:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_rateControlMode</a> - Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality
--   will match the specified quality level except when it is constrained
--   by the maximum bitrate. Recommended if you or your viewers pay for
--   bandwidth. VBR: Quality and bitrate vary, depending on the video
--   complexity. Recommended instead of QVBR if you want to maintain a
--   specific average bitrate over the duration of the channel. CBR:
--   Quality varies, depending on the video complexity. Recommended only if
--   you distribute your assets to devices that cannot handle variable
--   bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control mode is only supported (and is
--   required) when the video is being delivered to a MediaLive Multiplex
--   in which case the rate control configuration is controlled by the
--   properties within the Multiplex Program.
--   
--   <a>$sel:qualityLevel:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_qualityLevel</a> - Leave as STANDARD_QUALITY or choose
--   a different value (which might result in additional costs to run the
--   channel). - ENHANCED_QUALITY: Produces a slightly better video quality
--   without an increase in the bitrate. Has an effect only when the Rate
--   control mode is QVBR or CBR. If this channel is in a MediaLive
--   multiplex, the value must be ENHANCED_QUALITY. - STANDARD_QUALITY:
--   Valid for any Rate control mode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:slices:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_slices</a> - Number
--   of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number of
--   macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorMetadata:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_colorMetadata</a> - Includes colorspace metadata in
--   the output.
--   
--   <a>$sel:entropyEncoding:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_entropyEncoding</a> - Entropy encoding mode. Use cabac
--   (must be in Main or High profile) or cavlc.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSizeUnits:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_gopSizeUnits</a> - Indicates if the gopSize is
--   specified in frames or seconds. If seconds the system will convert the
--   gopSize into a frame count at run time.
--   
--   <a>$sel:subgopLength:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_subgopLength</a> - If set to fixed, use gopNumBFrames
--   B-frames per sub-GOP. If set to dynamic, optimize the number of
--   B-frames used for each sub-GOP to improve visual quality.
--   
--   <a>$sel:softness:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_softness</a> -
--   Softness. Selects quantizer matrix, larger values reduce
--   high-frequency content in the encoded image. If not set to zero, must
--   be greater than 15.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateDenominator:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_framerateDenominator</a> - Framerate denominator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:fixedAfd:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_fixedAfd</a> -
--   Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopSize:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_gopSize</a> - GOP
--   size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
--   
--   <a>$sel:filterSettings:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_filterSettings</a> - Optional filters that you can
--   apply to an encode.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parNumerator:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_parNumerator</a> - Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopNumBFrames:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_gopNumBFrames</a> - Number of B-frames between
--   reference frames.
--   
--   <a>$sel:spatialAq:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_spatialAq</a> -
--   Spatial AQ makes adjustments within each frame based on spatial
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if spatial AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
--   the Adaptive quantization field to a strength, you can set this field
--   to Enabled or Disabled. Enabled: MediaLive will apply spatial AQ using
--   the specified strength. Disabled: MediaLive won't apply spatial AQ. If
--   you have set the Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive ignores
--   any value in this field and doesn't apply spatial AQ.
--   
--   <a>$sel:timecodeInsertion:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_timecodeInsertion</a> - Determines how timecodes
--   should be inserted into the video elementary stream. - 'disabled': Do
--   not include timecodes - 'picTimingSei': Pass through picture timing
--   SEI messages from the source specified in Timecode Config
--   
--   <a>$sel:sceneChangeDetect:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_sceneChangeDetect</a> - Scene change detection. - On:
--   inserts I-frames when scene change is detected. - Off: does not force
--   an I-frame when scene change is detected.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parControl:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_parControl</a> -
--   This field indicates how the output pixel aspect ratio is specified.
--   If "specified" is selected then the output video pixel aspect ratio is
--   determined by parNumerator and parDenominator, else if
--   "initializeFromSource" is selected then the output pixsel aspect ratio
--   will be set equal to the input video pixel aspect ratio of the first
--   input.
--   
--   <a>$sel:colorSpaceSettings:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_colorSpaceSettings</a> - Color Space settings
--   
--   <a>$sel:minIInterval:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_minIInterval</a> - Only meaningful if
--   sceneChangeDetect is set to enabled. Defaults to 5 if multiplex rate
--   control is used. Enforces separation between repeated (cadence)
--   I-frames and I-frames inserted by Scene Change Detection. If a scene
--   change I-frame is within I-interval frames of a cadence I-frame, the
--   GOP is shrunk and/or stretched to the scene change I-frame. GOP
--   stretch requires enabling lookahead as well as setting I-interval. The
--   normal cadence resumes for the next GOP. Note: Maximum GOP stretch =
--   GOP size + Min-I-interval - 1
--   
--   <a>$sel:qvbrQualityLevel:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_qvbrQualityLevel</a> - Controls the target quality for
--   the video encode. Applies only when the rate control mode is QVBR. You
--   can set a target quality or you can let MediaLive determine the best
--   quality. To set a target quality, enter values in the QVBR quality
--   level field and the Max bitrate field. Enter values that suit your
--   most important viewing devices. Recommended values are: - Primary
--   screen: Quality level: 8 to 10. Max bitrate: 4M - PC or tablet:
--   Quality level: 7. Max bitrate: 1.5M to 3M - Smartphone: Quality level:
--   6. Max bitrate: 1M to 1.5M To let MediaLive decide, leave the QVBR
--   quality level field empty, and in Max bitrate enter the maximum rate
--   you want in the video. For more information, see the section called
--   "Video - rate control mode" in the MediaLive user guide
--   
--   <a>$sel:gopClosedCadence:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_gopClosedCadence</a> - Frequency of closed GOPs. In
--   streaming applications, it is recommended that this be set to 1 so a
--   decoder joining mid-stream will receive an IDR frame as quickly as
--   possible. Setting this value to 0 will break output segmenting.
--   
--   <a>$sel:parDenominator:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_parDenominator</a> - Pixel Aspect Ratio denominator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bufFillPct:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_bufFillPct</a> -
--   Percentage of the buffer that should initially be filled (HRD buffer
--   model).
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxBitrate:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_maxBitrate</a> -
--   For QVBR: See the tooltip for Quality level For VBR: Set the maximum
--   bitrate in order to accommodate expected spikes in the complexity of
--   the video.
--   
--   <a>$sel:syntax:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_syntax</a> -
--   Produces a bitstream compliant with SMPTE RP-2027.
--   
--   <a>$sel:numRefFrames:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_numRefFrames</a> - Number of reference frames to use.
--   The encoder may use more than requested if using B-frames and/or
--   interlaced encoding.
--   
--   <a>$sel:level:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_level</a> - H.264
--   Level.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lookAheadRateControl:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_lookAheadRateControl</a> - Amount of lookahead. A
--   value of low can decrease latency and memory usage, while high can
--   produce better quality for certain content.
--   
--   <a>$sel:profile:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_profile</a> - H.264
--   Profile.
--   
--   <a>$sel:adaptiveQuantization:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_adaptiveQuantization</a> - Enables or disables
--   adaptive quantization, which is a technique MediaLive can apply to
--   video on a frame-by-frame basis to produce more compression without
--   losing quality. There are three types of adaptive quantization:
--   flicker, spatial, and temporal. Set the field in one of these ways:
--   Set to Auto. Recommended. For each type of AQ, MediaLive will
--   determine if AQ is needed, and if so, the appropriate strength. Set a
--   strength (a value other than Auto or Disable). This strength will
--   apply to any of the AQ fields that you choose to enable. Set to
--   Disabled to disable all types of adaptive quantization.
--   
--   <a>$sel:framerateControl:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_framerateControl</a> - This field indicates how the
--   output video frame rate is specified. If "specified" is selected then
--   the output video frame rate is determined by framerateNumerator and
--   framerateDenominator, else if "initializeFromSource" is selected then
--   the output video frame rate will be set equal to the input video frame
--   rate of the first input.
--   
--   <a>$sel:forceFieldPictures:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_forceFieldPictures</a> - This setting applies only
--   when scan type is "interlaced." It controls whether coding is
--   performed on a field basis or on a frame basis. (When the video is
--   progressive, the coding is always performed on a frame basis.)
--   enabled: Force MediaLive to code on a field basis, so that odd and
--   even sets of fields are coded separately. disabled: Code the two sets
--   of fields separately (on a field basis) or together (on a frame basis
--   using PAFF), depending on what is most appropriate for the content.
--   
--   <a>$sel:bitrate:H264Settings'</a>, <a>h264Settings_bitrate</a> -
--   Average bitrate in bits/second. Required when the rate control mode is
--   VBR or CBR. Not used for QVBR. In an MS Smooth output group, each
--   output must have a unique value when its bitrate is rounded down to
--   the nearest multiple of 1000.
--   
--   <a>$sel:afdSignaling:H264Settings'</a>,
--   <a>h264Settings_afdSignaling</a> - Indicates that AFD values will be
--   written into the output stream. If afdSignaling is "auto", the system
--   will try to preserve the input AFD value (in cases where multiple AFD
--   values are valid). If set to "fixed", the AFD value will be the value
--   configured in the fixedAfd parameter.
newH264Settings :: H264Settings

-- | Sets the scan type of the output to progressive or top-field-first
--   interlaced.
h264Settings_scanType :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264ScanType)

-- | Temporal makes adjustments within each frame based on temporal
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if temporal AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
--   the Adaptive quantization field to a strength, you can set this field
--   to Enabled or Disabled. Enabled: MediaLive will apply temporal AQ
--   using the specified strength. Disabled: MediaLive won't apply temporal
--   AQ. If you have set the Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive
--   ignores any value in this field and doesn't apply temporal AQ.
h264Settings_temporalAq :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264TemporalAq)

-- | Size of buffer (HRD buffer model) in bits.
h264Settings_bufSize :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Flicker AQ makes adjustments within each frame to reduce flicker or
--   'pop' on I-frames. The value to enter in this field depends on the
--   value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have set the Adaptive
--   quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any value in this field.
--   MediaLive will determine if flicker AQ is appropriate and will apply
--   the appropriate strength. If you have set the Adaptive quantization
--   field to a strength, you can set this field to Enabled or Disabled.
--   Enabled: MediaLive will apply flicker AQ using the specified strength.
--   Disabled: MediaLive won't apply flicker AQ. If you have set the
--   Adaptive quantization to Disabled, MediaLive ignores any value in this
--   field and doesn't apply flicker AQ.
h264Settings_flickerAq :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264FlickerAq)

-- | Documentation update needed
h264Settings_gopBReference :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264GopBReference)

-- | Framerate numerator - framerate is a fraction, e.g. 24000 / 1001 =
--   23.976 fps.
h264Settings_framerateNumerator :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Rate control mode. QVBR: Quality will match the specified quality
--   level except when it is constrained by the maximum bitrate.
--   Recommended if you or your viewers pay for bandwidth. VBR: Quality and
--   bitrate vary, depending on the video complexity. Recommended instead
--   of QVBR if you want to maintain a specific average bitrate over the
--   duration of the channel. CBR: Quality varies, depending on the video
--   complexity. Recommended only if you distribute your assets to devices
--   that cannot handle variable bitrates. Multiplex: This rate control
--   mode is only supported (and is required) when the video is being
--   delivered to a MediaLive Multiplex in which case the rate control
--   configuration is controlled by the properties within the Multiplex
--   Program.
h264Settings_rateControlMode :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264RateControlMode)

-- | Leave as STANDARD_QUALITY or choose a different value (which might
--   result in additional costs to run the channel). - ENHANCED_QUALITY:
--   Produces a slightly better video quality without an increase in the
--   bitrate. Has an effect only when the Rate control mode is QVBR or CBR.
--   If this channel is in a MediaLive multiplex, the value must be
--   ENHANCED_QUALITY. - STANDARD_QUALITY: Valid for any Rate control mode.
h264Settings_qualityLevel :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264QualityLevel)

-- | Number of slices per picture. Must be less than or equal to the number
--   of macroblock rows for progressive pictures, and less than or equal to
--   half the number of macroblock rows for interlaced pictures. This field
--   is optional; when no value is specified the encoder will choose the
--   number of slices based on encode resolution.
h264Settings_slices :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Includes colorspace metadata in the output.
h264Settings_colorMetadata :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264ColorMetadata)

-- | Entropy encoding mode. Use cabac (must be in Main or High profile) or
--   cavlc.
h264Settings_entropyEncoding :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264EntropyEncoding)

-- | Indicates if the gopSize is specified in frames or seconds. If seconds
--   the system will convert the gopSize into a frame count at run time.
h264Settings_gopSizeUnits :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264GopSizeUnits)

-- | If set to fixed, use gopNumBFrames B-frames per sub-GOP. If set to
--   dynamic, optimize the number of B-frames used for each sub-GOP to
--   improve visual quality.
h264Settings_subgopLength :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264SubGopLength)

-- | Softness. Selects quantizer matrix, larger values reduce
--   high-frequency content in the encoded image. If not set to zero, must
--   be greater than 15.
h264Settings_softness :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Framerate denominator.
h264Settings_framerateDenominator :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Four bit AFD value to write on all frames of video in the output
--   stream. Only valid when afdSignaling is set to 'Fixed'.
h264Settings_fixedAfd :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe FixedAfd)

-- | GOP size (keyframe interval) in units of either frames or seconds per
--   gopSizeUnits. If gopSizeUnits is frames, gopSize must be an integer
--   and must be greater than or equal to 1. If gopSizeUnits is seconds,
--   gopSize must be greater than 0, but need not be an integer.
h264Settings_gopSize :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Double)

-- | Optional filters that you can apply to an encode.
h264Settings_filterSettings :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe H264FilterSettings)

-- | Pixel Aspect Ratio numerator.
h264Settings_parNumerator :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Number of B-frames between reference frames.
h264Settings_gopNumBFrames :: Lens' H264Settings (Maybe Natural)

-- | Spatial AQ makes adjustments within each frame based on spatial
--   variation of content complexity. The value to enter in this field
--   depends on the value in the Adaptive quantization field: If you have
--   set the Adaptive quantization field to Auto, MediaLive ignores any
--   value in this field. MediaLive will determine if spatial AQ is
--   appropriate and will apply the appropriate strength. If you have set
